item.title: Comment on Sunday assorted links by Dave T
item.description:
Reply to Aristophanes:

The stat is "Billboard Top 100 Number 1 hits". So it only counts songs that hit #1. (If the pattern for all top 100 hits was markedly different though, that would be interesting).

A broder metric would be better, I suspect it would also show a declining trend, though of course not going to zero.

My take on underlying reasons:

- Increase in % of hits that are rap songs. Rap doesn't really have covers. (Rap songs do, however, often sample well-known songs. That's essentially rap's version of "covers".)

- Rise of streaming services. The older original songs are now readily available. Indeed, can sometimes cause a bit of confusion when searching for a cover song on Spotify or Apple Music. Particularly if the style of the cover isn't that differentiated from the original.

- Think that prevalence of hit cover songs was heavily influenced by common marketing and promotion strategies from major labels, back when those labels dominated the music scene in a way that they no longer do. It could be a "safe" marketing strategy for a cover to be the 2nd or 3rd single from an album. Ties back to the prior point, as a younger generation sometimes might not even be aware that the song is a cover.

It’s also very easy for me to see how fortunes could be won or lost on an election night, when prices fluctuate wildly as results come in, simply by manipulating the flow of information — exit polls, early election results, and especially recount related information. The way we release and announce election results in the US is already painful and stupid. Why do anything to make it worse?

Having said that, I consumed content on PredictIt and it made me smarter — it was both a measure of *cough* well-informed opinion, and as a sanity check for my own opinions. And I certainly enjoyed placing the occasional bet (never on a race I worked). No strong feeling here, I just don’t think the issue is as clear cut as Tyler argues given the specter of insider trading.

item.title: Comment on There is simply no good reason for such a ruling by blue jay
item.description:
Reply to M:

European football leagues are uh... not exactly against money.

Is there an economic defense of ticket scalping? I thought that clubs don't like it (and seek to prevent it) because it reduces their share of the profit on ticket sales, and punters don't like it because they'd rather for whatever price x the ticket was supplied at, more of the profit went back into the club. There doesn't seem like any economically useful role scalpers play in speculating on the price that they can resell it for.

"Is there an economic defense of ticket scalping? "

Is there an argument against it? How is it different than trading a stock by buying it at a lower price and selling it at a higher price?

As I've pointed out before, I trade in several markets. I frequently sell to buyers who don't have time or inclination to sit around waiting for every screaming low price offer. I spend my time doing that and, in effect, they pay me for my trouble when I offer products to them at a higher price - a price that protects the item from people who would otherwise buy it just because it's cheap. IOW, I sell to people who want it the most for what it is.

It's perfectly legitimate to function as a middleman to channel products to people who want them the most.
